Notes: Check if it is moving left to right. They check blocks next to each other starting from the very left. If they don't swap go to the 2nd and 3rd blocks. If they do swap then check if there are any more swaps with previous blocks. Then go back to where you were.

KEYS TO OMGNE SORT
If a pair changes places, you have to check backwards
If a pair does not change places, you go forward
After checking forward, go back to where you left off.
(For example, if 3 and 4 switch places, you have to go backwards to check, then you start back at 4 by checking 4 and 5)

Step 1: Designate the leftmost object as Object A.

Step 2: Check if swapping Object A with its right neighbor is valid (based on a predefined rule, such as its weight).

If invalid, designate the right neighbor as the new Object A and repeat Step 2.

If valid, swap their positions, designate the swapped neighbor as Object B, note Object Aâ€™s position, and proceed to Step 3.

Step 3: Propagate Object B to the left, following the same logic as Step 2 but with two changes:

The goal direction is now left.

If a swap fails, assume Object B is sorted and return to Step 2 and remember Object A's position.

Starting with the left-most block, click on the block and the one to its right. If they swap, try to swap the one that just moved with the one to the left. Continue until no more swaps occur, and then proceed to the right.

Start by comparing the first two blocks. Then progress by comparing the blocks in the 2nd and 3rd position, and then the 3rd and 4th, and so on.

Whenever a swap happens, keep note of the "leading" block that was placed ahead (to the right). If a swap does not happen, the block on the right that was compared becomes the new "leading" block. The block that was just swapped behind the "leading" block then needs to be compared to the block behind it. If a swap happens, again compare it to the block behind it. Repeat this until a swap does not happen or until it is placed in the first position. Then return to your "leading" block and compare it to the block ahead of it.

If they swap places, that's ok. The goal of the game is to put the gold blocks in order. Repeat this method for every block. The goal is to order the blocks correctly with minimal attempts/moves. Instead of using a compare the first block to the second block, then compare the first block to the third block, etc., the Omgne Sort is a more direct and less repetitive sorting system which doesn't repeat steps over and over. The Omgne Sort compares the first block to the second and then the second to the third. Only when there is an actual block swap do you then go backwards in your possible swapping of blocks, i.e. if the fourth and fifth blocks swap, then you go backwards trying to swap blocks until they don't swap anymore.

Quick Guide to Identifying Omgne Sort Patterns
Omgne Sort is all about efficiently sorting items by comparing pairs and swapping when necessary. To improve your accuracy and speed, here's a breakdown of key patterns:

1. Recognizing the Order of Items:
Least Out-of-Order: Only one swap is needed, meaning the items are almost sorted. Look for just one misplaced item.
Somewhat Out-of-Order: A few swaps are needed. The items are not far from sorted but have a few minor adjustments required.
Very Out-of-Order: Multiple swaps are needed to arrange the items in order. This means the items are fairly scrambled.
Most Out-of-Order: This requires the maximum number of swaps. Items are in a completely reversed or scrambled order.
2. Tips for Faster Sorting:
Start with the Extremes: Compare the items at the ends (heaviest vs. lightest) to get a sense of their order.
Minimize Comparisons: After each comparison, update the list to focus only on what still needs sorting.
Work in Small Sections: If you have 8 items, focus on smaller groups (like the first 3 or 4) to build a sorted base.
3. Practice Makes Perfect:
Familiarize Yourself with Patterns: Recognize when the arrangement is close to sorted and when it needs more adjustments.
Stay Calm and Focused: If you get stuck, step back and compare a new pair to continue the process.
